Another question here: why did you remove the range parameter?
I didn't find an easy way to retrieve that from the PC. I admit I didn't look hard for it, because vscode seems to handle it pretty well even without it.
As per the check, it'd be weird that `tree.tpe.widen` would return an empty string. I suppose if it ever comes up we can handle it pretty easily :)

Works great! üíØ So cool!
And yes, I thought that without range symbols won't be highlighted correctly, but both VS Code and Atom handle it very well.
should we also preload all existing `compilerconfig`files at launch, similarly to what we do with `semanticdb` files?
We do actually, since we call this method from loadAllSemanticdbs... method, I've renamed the method to be more descriptive.
NB, we should really run that method asynchronously from the initialize method since it slows down server startup.

Yeah, in general I think initialize should return immediately and run the rest of the work asynchronously. We can even dynamically register for capabilities when the single services finish initializing.
why is the overflow strategy gone?
I added it without knowing what it does. I think we should use the default unless we know what we're doing.

comments.body: cc/ @alexandru can you perhaps explain the difference between `Observable.merge[T](Observable*).subscribe()` and `List[Observable[T])].map(_.subscribe())`? Our tests passed with List but fail with merge, intuitively I would expect them to behave similarly.

Don't know what your test is doing, but one thing to be aware of is that `merge` introduces a buffer between the observables pushing the events and the subscriber. And in testing this could mean extra async boundaries, because the consumer is no longer consuming from the same thread as the producers.

Interesting, thanks for the explanation. In our tests we use `TestScheduler` and `tickOne` as much as possible https://github.com/scalameta/language-server/blob/617d8644922f379f0d0a874c679aaa04347c92f5/metaserver/src/test/scala/tests/search/SymbolIndexTest.scala#L47  Looking at the logs, it seems the ordering of events is slightly different with/without merge.

Cheers üçª
Ah yes, so ordering can be a problem ‚Äî `merge` is non-deterministic, creating a race between the participating producers.

Our tests don't rely on ordering as far I can tell, but I'll need closer look to verify.

Understanding `merge` better will help me keep an eye out for this in the future. So far Observable[T] has been amazing, this PR was a decent refactoring and all tests passed on first compile üòÑ  `.merge` causing the tests to fail came as a surprise however, but I wouldn't be surprised if the tests need a refactoring too!

comments.body: We should create nonjar uris for all references, otherwise those don't appear in the results. However, we currently only index definitions positions in mtags so I don't think we'll have references to jar uris besides definitions.

There's a different problem here: 
1. If you have `List` mentioned in your code and call find-references, you will get just references in _your code_
2. Then if you call go-to-definition, it will create a file in `target/sources/`
3. Now if you call find-references again, mentions of `List` in that created source will also be among the results.

This happens because LSP AFAIK doesn't have a concept of source directories, for it all files of the given language scope in the workspace are project sources. So those files we will create in `target/sources` will be added to the mix.

I think we have two options here

- create source files in target/source/* in references
- ignore references in jar:file uris

I lean towards the second option.
Me too
Can we update the comment to reflect that we intentionally skip jar:file uris?

comments.body:
I think Observable stops on the first error so this is not enough to continue streaming configuration. I tried
```scala
    import monix.execution.Scheduler.Implicits.global
    val o = Observable
      .fromIterable(1.to(10))
      .map {
        case 5 => sys.error("5")
        case n => n + 1
      }
      .doOnError(e => println(s"EREEEEEEEEEE $e"))
    o.foreach(println)
```
and it prints out

```
2
3
4
5
EREEEEEEEEEE java.lang.RuntimeException: 5
```

I think it's best to avoid exceptions and do something like this instead
```scala
    import monix.execution.Scheduler.Implicits.global
    val o = Observable
      .fromIterable(1.to(10))
      .map {
        case 5 => Left(5)
        case n => Right(n)
      }
      .doOnNext {
        case Left(err) => println(s"FAIL $err")
        case _ => ()
      }
      .collect {
        case Right(x) => x
      }
    o.foreach(println)
```

which prints
```
1
2
3
4
FAIL 5
6
7
8
9
10
```

Alternatively, 

```scala
    val o = Observable
      .fromIterable(1.to(10))
      .liftByOperator[Int] { out =>
        new Subscriber[Int] {
          override implicit def scheduler: Scheduler = out.scheduler
          override def onError(ex: Throwable): Unit = out.onError(ex)
          override def onComplete(): Unit = out.onComplete()
          override def onNext(elem: Int): Future[Ack] = elem match {
            case 5 =>
              println("FAIL 5")
              Ack.Continue
            case n =>
              out.onNext(n)
          }
        }
      }
    o.foreach(println)
```
which prints the same.
very nice catch, thank you!
